head.title: Chevy Looks East for a Small-Scale Hatchback

hedline.hl1: Chevy Looks East for a Small-Scale Hatchback

block.p: Introduced on Wednesday: Chevrolet Trax, Beat and Groove
Are they real? Definitely in Asia, where one of these models will replace the current Chevy Spark around 2010. The United States remains on hold for now.
Introduced on Wednesday: Chevrolet Trax, Beat and Groove
Are they real? Definitely in Asia, where one of these models will replace the current Chevy Spark around 2010. The United States remains on hold for now.

What's the point? G.M.'s South Korean design studio is driving the creation of a global subcompact car, and Chevrolet is using the auto show to audition this trio of miniature hatchbacks including an American Idol-style Web vote to decide showgoers' favorite, at www.voteforchevrolet.com

What they said: "It's the perfect urban S.U.V.," said G.M.'s design chief, Ed Welburn, while a group of youngsters began gyrating onstage like an iPod commercial come to life. (Note to G.M. Choreography Department: actual cool kids don't wear Rolling Stones t-shirts).
What they didn't say: Whether there's a big enough market in America's supersized culture for the kind of half-pint, lightly powered cars that dominate Europe and the Far East.

What makes it tick? The Trax has a 1-liter 3-cylinder engine with 50 horsepower; the Beat gets a turbo 1.4-liter 4-cylinder; and the Groove is the mileage champ with a 1-liter diesel that would top 50 miles per gallon.
How much, how soon? No sooner than 2010 for the U.S., priced like your typical budget mobile around $11,000-$12,000 to start.
How's it look? Not bad for starter-car subcompacts, especially the wide-eyed, pug-nosed Trax.
